poem:
**Morning Read**

A brilliant woman
locked in a cage of syllables,
a man puffed up on the fumes
of his own mediocrity,
both trapped in the quiet pages
of a newspaper review,
their lives unfolding on the kitchen table
as I sip coffee,
wondering how brilliance and banality
come together
to ruin the morning.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Liars by Sarah Manguso review – searing tale of a toxic marriage A brilliant, imaginative woman; a mediocre man with too high an idea of himself, in need of a woman to destroy. It’s a dynamic that goes back to George Eliot’s Middlemarch or Henry James’s The Portrait of a Lady, novels that wreaked havoc with conventional ideas about to whom brilliance is meant to belong and forced the reader to see how grindingly limited these". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
